items.title: ‘Butt breathing’ could help people who can’t get oxygen the regular way
items.description: Takanori Takebe’s strange investigation into whether humans can use the gut for breathing has surprisingly sentimental origins: helping his dad.
items.content: Takanori Takebe’s strange investigation into whether humans can use the gut for breathing has surprisingly sentimental origins: helping his dad.

items.title: Rats are snatching bats out of the air and eating them
items.description: The grisly infrared camera footage records a never-before-seen hunting tactic. It may have implications for bat conservation.
items.content: The grisly infrared camera footage records a never-before-seen hunting tactic. It may have implications for bat conservation.

items.title: 3,000 steps per day might slow Alzheimer’s disease
items.description: In people at risk for Alzheimer’s disease, researchers linked minimal to moderate physical activity to a 3-to 7-year delay in cognitive symptoms.
items.content: In people at risk for Alzheimer’s disease, researchers linked minimal to moderate physical activity to a 3-to 7-year delay in cognitive symptoms.

items.title: A historic year for U.S. science
items.description: Nancy Shute, Editor in Chief, discusses big advances across science in 2025 as well as the assault on science by the Trump administration.
items.content: Nancy Shute, Editor in Chief, discusses big advances across science in 2025 as well as the assault on science by the Trump administration.

items.title: Meet 5 scientists reshaping the way we understand the world
items.description: These five early- and mid-career researchers are shaking up what we know about the Arctic, black holes and beyond.
items.content: These five early- and mid-career researchers are shaking up what we know about the Arctic, black holes and beyond.

items.title: Science has made America great. Is that era over?
items.description: Expectations of continued success for American science were shaken this year when the Trump administration cut billions of dollars in funding and fired thousands of scientists.
items.content: Expectations of continued success for American science were shaken this year when the Trump administration cut billions of dollars in funding and fired thousands of scientists.

items.title: A new dinosaur doomsday exhibit showcases survival after destruction
items.description: The American Museum of Natural History’s “Impact: The End of the Age of the Dinosaurs” examines how an asteroid impact shaped life as we know it.
items.content: The American Museum of Natural History’s “Impact: The End of the Age of the Dinosaurs” examines how an asteroid impact shaped life as we know it.

items.title: Building a better skin barrier
items.description: Skin is a barrier meant to keep small invaders out. Products making their way across it should boost that mission.
items.content: Skin is a barrier meant to keep small invaders out. Products making their way across it should boost that mission.

items.title: Math puzzle: A Loopy Holiday Gift Exchange
items.description: Solve the math puzzle from our December 2025 issue, in which a holiday gift exchange occurs.
items.content: Solve the math puzzle from our December 2025 issue, in which a holiday gift exchange occurs.

items.title: Here’s how Rudolph’s light-up nose might be possible
items.description: Simple chemistry could give the reindeer his famously bright snout. But physics would make it look different colors from the ground.
items.content: Simple chemistry could give the reindeer his famously bright snout. But physics would make it look different colors from the ground.

items.title: Lions have a second roar that no one noticed until now
items.description: A machine learning analysis of wild lion audio reveals they have two roar types, not one. This insight might help detect where lions are declining.
items.content: A machine learning analysis of wild lion audio reveals they have two roar types, not one. This insight might help detect where lions are declining.

items.title: A diet low in glutamate may ease migraines
items.description: People with Gulf War Illness found relief from migraines after a month on a low-glutamate diet, hinting at a new way to ease symptoms.
items.content: People with Gulf War Illness found relief from migraines after a month on a low-glutamate diet, hinting at a new way to ease symptoms.

items.title: These are Science News’ favorite books of 2025
items.description: Books about AI, Mars and infectious disease were among our top reads this year.
items.content: Books about AI, Mars and infectious disease were among our top reads this year.

items.title: America risks losing its role as a space science pioneer
items.description: Funding uncertainties are pushing U.S. space scientists out of the field and putting existing and future space missions on the chopping block.
items.content: Funding uncertainties are pushing U.S. space scientists out of the field and putting existing and future space missions on the chopping block.

items.title: Moss spores survived in space for 9 months
items.description: The moss species Physcomitrium patens is the latest organism to survive an extended stay in the vacuum and radiation of space.
items.content: The moss species Physcomitrium patens is the latest organism to survive an extended stay in the vacuum and radiation of space.

items.title: mRNA flu vaccines are making their way through clinical trials
items.description: The mRNA platform offers the advantage of faster vaccine production, which could allow more time to decide on which flu strains to cover.
items.content: The mRNA platform offers the advantage of faster vaccine production, which could allow more time to decide on which flu strains to cover.

items.title: In animal tests, this needle-free insulin acted as fast as injections
items.description: Managing diabetes with injections is challenging. Joining insulin to a skin-penetrating polymer was as effective as shots at regulating blood sugar.
items.content: Managing diabetes with injections is challenging. Joining insulin to a skin-penetrating polymer was as effective as shots at regulating blood sugar.

items.title: Eroding access to childhood vaccines jeopardizes health for all
items.description: Recent U.S. decisions about vaccines signal bigger changes to come that could threaten the foundation of the national childhood immunization schedule.
items.content: Recent U.S. decisions about vaccines signal bigger changes to come that could threaten the foundation of the national childhood immunization schedule.

items.title: Combining western science with Indigenous knowledge could help the Arctic
items.description: Polar marine ecologist Marianne Falardeau investigates how Arctic ecosystems are shifting under climate change.
items.content: Polar marine ecologist Marianne Falardeau investigates how Arctic ecosystems are shifting under climate change.

items.title: See the alarming extent of NIH and NSF funding cuts in 2025
items.description: In 2025, the Trump administration froze or ended about 5,300 NIH and NSF research grants totaling over $5 billion in unspent funds, a decision that reshaped many fields of science.
items.content: In 2025, the Trump administration froze or ended about 5,300 NIH and NSF research grants totaling over $5 billion in unspent funds, a decision that reshaped many fields of science.
